hotspots.label: Bee's Body Parts
hotspots.fact: Bees have special body parts that help them survive and do their jobs! They have large eyes to see flowers, fuzzy bodies to collect pollen, and six legs to hold onto flowers while they eat. All these features help bees get the food they need to live.

vocabulary.definition: The different sections of an animal's body, like legs, wings, and eyes, that help it do important things like move, see, and eat.

hotspots.label: Pollen on Bee
hotspots.fact: See the yellow dusty powder on the bee's body? That's pollen! When the bee visits flowers to drink nectar, pollen sticks to its fuzzy fur. This is called **pollination** — when the bee flies to the next flower, it carries pollen that helps plants make seeds and fruits.

vocabulary.definition: The movement of pollen from one flower to another, usually by bees or other animals, so plants can make seeds.

hotspots.label: Purple Flower
hotspots.fact: This purple flower is the bee's habitat and food source! The flower provides nectar, a sweet liquid that bees drink for energy, and pollen for protein. Without bees visiting flowers, many plants couldn't make new seeds, so bees and flowers need each other to survive.

vocabulary.definition: The place where an animal lives and finds food, water, and shelter. For a bee, flowers are part of its habitat.

hotspots.label: Bee's Wings
hotspots.fact: Bees have four delicate wings that help them fly from flower to flower to find food. These wings beat very fast—about 200 times per second! Fast wings help bees move quickly to visit many flowers in a day.

vocabulary.definition: A special body part or behavior that helps an animal survive in its environment. Wings are an adaptation that helps bees find food.
